data.title: [Request]Documentation of one way collision
data.body: The usage of one way collision in PhysicsBody2D.

data.title: [suggestion] moving scripts tabs : replace Ctrl+Left and Ctrl+Right with something else
data.body:
Hi,

Tested under windows with recent compiled source code.

Into the script editor, when several scripts are opened, it is possible to change their Tab ordering using the "Move Left" and "Move Right" menu items into the "Window" menu.

These menu items are currently associated to the keyboard shortcuts Ctrl+Left and Ctrl+Right.

However, these two shortcuts only work when the "window" menu is opened, because Ctrl+Left and Ctrl+Right are also used into the script editor to move the cursor to the next or previous tocken.

This render these shortcuts useless. They should be changed to something else.

data.title: Cant hide CanvasModulate
data.body: It seems like there is some problem with all CanvasItem options in CanvasModulate. 'Visible' checkbox doesn't work, so as all other options there. In order to hide it, you need to delete it basically.

data.title: Two colliding KinematicBody2D might push one another
data.body:
Create a scene file that contains the following:
- KinematicsBody2D
  - Sprite
  - CollisionShape2D

Set the CollisionShape2D to a reasonable size (in my case, it was 16x48 as my sprite is 32x96).

From another scene, instantiate this scene using the + button that says "Instance a Node from scene file".  Create two instances of this scene, let's call them A and B, and put them side by side, separated by a couple hundred pixels or so.

Create a script for instance B, and instruct it to move toward A.  This is an example script that instructs B to keep moving to the left:

```
extends KinematicBody2D

var speed = 100.0
var movement_vector = Vector2(-1, 0)

func _ready():
    set_fixed_process(true)
    pass

func _fixed_process(delta):
    var motion = move(movement_vector * speed * delta)
```

Then create another script for A that takes input from player and have it move up and down.

```
extends KinematicBody2D

var movement_speed = 100

func _ready():
  set_fixed_process(true)
  pass

func _fixed_process(delta):
  if Input.is_action_pressed("ui_up"):
    move(Vector2(0, -movement_speed) * delta)
  if Input.is_action_pressed("ui_down"):
    move(Vector2(0, movement_speed) * delta)
```

Run the scene.  Wait until B hits A, both objects will collide and stop moving.  Then wiggle A by pressing up and down repeatedly, you will notice B will slowly push A on the X axis to the side, even though A isn't supposed to be moving along the X axis.

data.title: No way to move camera in editor
data.body: There is no way to move camera in editor when no scrollbars are displayed ( when there is no object out of the current view area ). It is very usefull to center the viewport while editing stuff - the GL space is "infinite", and the scrollbars just limit it much.

data.title: Set PolygonOcculer2d same as drawn polygon
data.body: There is no option to set the PolygonOcculer2d geometry exactly the same as drawn Polygon2D. Of course there is an option to set material to PolygonOcculer2d, so there should be no reason to use Polygon2d anymore, but there is a Texture in Polygon2d, which is easier and faster in use. It should be unified somehow here, because is almost the same, but it works in a different way.

data.title: Camera moving while moving node
data.body: It's pretty annoying, when moving an object around the working area in editor, because camera slides with mouse when the object is near viewport border. It's almost impossible to set objects position exactly when you want to. Please let user to decide whenever he wants to move camera or not.

data.title: 2D light direction / normals problem (?)
data.body: It seems like 2d light has some direction or something, but there is no way to control it. The light texture is displayed only in the half in some direction. Are normals wrong interpreted or something? Because there is no such problem when disabling normal texture. It looks, like normals is problem here.

data.title: swapped coords in 2d light normal mapping
data.body: It seems to me, that y coord is swapped with -y and vice versa in 2d lighting normals. Correct me if I'm wrong please.

data.title: 2d light disappears near the sprite's top or left border
data.body: 2D light disappears, when it's close to the sprite's top or left bound with the opposite ( bottom/right) light texture side. The distance is const in vierport space, so the closer the camera is, the smaller the distance looks to be in games coords.

data.title: 2d Shadow->Enabled  - stange rectangle drawing
data.body: After enabling shadows on 2d light some strange white rectangle appears on the top of the working area. New one appears for each new shadow enabled light, while the previous ones moves down making space for the new one.

data.title: supports SDLs joystick database format and remaps joystick events
data.body:
This is the patch with the code that supports SDL's joystick database and remaps the joystick events to ones in our own input event, implemented on the Windows OS. To test on other OSs, instance "InputPC" instead of InputDefault, and call the joy_button, joy_hat, joy_axis functions instead of creating the InputEvent structure directly in the OS.

There's a couple of things missing:
- On Linux we're not reading the input events with the same method SDL uses, so our events are different (we have no hat).
- I'm not sure how SDL obtains the GUID for the joystick, I saw somewhere that it was the first 16 characters from the name (this is what I implemented here), but some of the GUIDs look like they won't be compatible with this.
- If it turns out that we also need this for mobile platforms (apparently we do, at least for Android), we should move all the code from InputPC back to InputDefaut

testing/comments will be appreciated

data.body: After pressing 'ok' on "No OcculerPolygon2D on this resource on this node. Create and assign one?", the godot crashes. It works fine if a new Occuler made on my own.

data.title: make editor preserve signal connections when replacing a target node by an other
data.body:
Hi,

I have a bunch of buttons that have their "pressed" signals connected to the script of the root-scene node.

If, into the Editor, I replace the scene-node by an other node type (for instance Node2D by Spatial node), then, all buttons signal connections are lost, and I have to reconnect them all manually.

It would be cool if signals connections were preserved when a node is replaced by an other into the Editor.

data.title: Breakpoint does persist after disabling it
data.body:
Steps to reproduce:
1. Toggle breakpoint on any source code line.
2. Start the game, do the game reaches the breakpoint and observe the game stops on the breakpoint.
3. Disable the breakpoint.
4. Continue the game, and you can see the game stops again when it reaches the line the breakpoint was, even if the breakpoint is disabled.

It seems to be that the debugger "remembers" the breakpoints enabled when the debug session starts and ignores you when you disable them during the debug session.

Tested on Godot 1.0, Mac OS X.

data.title: Detect multiple monitors using Xinerama extension for fullscreen
data.body:
This is my second attempt to fix #1408. I tested in Ubuntu 14.10 with the
Unity desktop, LXDE, and OpenBox and it worked as expected in all three.

This change includes the Xinerama extension and queries it when going
fullscreen. Xinerama has information about the actual monitors
connected in a multi-monitor configuration. X normally treats both
monitors as a single large screen. Xinerama allows us to get the
actual dimensions of attached screens. Nvidia TwinView and other
drivers use the Xinerama protocol so this should be compatible with
most multi-screen setups.

This forces fullscreen to always go to screen 0. This fixes #1408.
This also fixes the issue in some window managers (e.g. LXDE and
OpenBox) where Godot would stretch across both monitors.
